Its the way lenses work. You can open it wider to let more light come in by setting it to a higher aperture. This is done with some blades that form in this case a hexagon. Google the term 'aperture blade' and you'll understand what i just said ;P

The same effect is used to make little hearts with the light blur in pictures! The shape of the aperture inside of the camera (the little window that opens to let light in and expose light to the image) changes the shape of the light that is blurred in the background. I am not going to pretend like I know the light physics behind this, but google "heart shaped bokeh" for cool examples of how it can be used for ART.

the core audience aught to be highly aware since he uses and talks about both of those methods quite often to illustrate how things work, but if this is someone's first episode, or they don't know much about photo/video/graphy then they might make that mistake easily.  Since this is a channel devoted to learning/informing, I thought I'd do my part in helping out :)

The camera has a 6-blade aperture system to limit the amount of light going into the camera. It shows as hexagons on bright lights and reflections that are out of focus. The more blades an aperture system has, the rounder it gets. :)

The aperture is the portion of a lens that determines how much light passes through to the camera. It i comes in various forms of perfect polygons, but the one for this lens is a hexagon. Because they are like this when things like light and in this case water droplets on the lens go out of focus they create this effect.

comment_text: This theory is based on just one equation (E= ˠ M˳C² )∞  the Lorentz contraction of space and time is between the energy and mass. The greater the energy the greater the contraction of space and the slower time will run. Mass will increase relative to this and each ref-frame can be seen as a vortex in space and time.
